page.title: 08Skull House, Appley Bridge
page.content: A visit to Skull House to inspect the discoloured human skull was both interesting and intriguing. No-one seems to know to whom the skull belonged as it has been at Skull House for so long that it seems unlikely the past will ever unfold its secret. It is reputed to be the harbinger of misfortune and ill-luck to those who handle it, or remove it from Skull House. Mrs. Smith, the present occupant, is not particularly superstitious, although she is very reluctant to remove the skull from the wooden casket in which it is kept. However, she does admit that in the fifteen years she has lived at Skull House, she hasn't encountered any ghostly happenings yet. The house itself is fascinating, with leaded windows decorated with skulls, massive beams and a priest's hole.
